HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 23, 1926.

MUSICAL CLUB TICKETS
ARE GOING FAST

The supply of tickets *for
the Annual Home Concert of
the Musical Club is disappearing so rapidly that those
who don't want to miss the
affair, which is to be held
Friday night a the Maryland
Casualty
Clubhouse, are
urged to get their reserved
seats at once, either from
Gordon Stick at the Barn or
down town at Aibaugh's
ticket office. The Home Concert has become an institution at Hopkins; it is an outstanding
feature in the university
calendar of events. It is the
big finale to which the Musical Club looks • forward
every year.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 23, 1926.

ON THE VARSITY SEAL
The Varsity Seal is undoubtedly a good looking affair.
Moreover, it is fairly characteristic of,the University; a Hopkins man will spot it anywhere, and immediately associate it
with his days at Hpmewood. In spite of, or perhaps because
of these qualities, the Seal is in danger of becoming cheapened
through overuse.
Every publication, pamphlet, circular or letter issued at
Homewood seems to bear the well-known imprint. Seals on
our right, seals on our left, seals in front of us, seals behind
us volley and thunder from the printed page. Our eyes are
dazzled by continuous lines of "Veritas Vos Liberabit" and
emblems and emblems indicating that heraldry is not a dead
art. Yes, the Varsity Seal is becoming common through overuse. And we all know the old crack about familiarity breeding
.contempt.
The latest example of this flagrant disregard of the proprieties in use of the University's seal comes to our eyes in the
clever little 'check letter' of the BLACK AND BLUE JAY. The
first thing that strikes our eyes is the seal at the top of the
card. Surely the letter would have been just as effective without its use.
The NEWS-LETTER calls for a little more discrimination in
the use of the Varsity Seal.

We have decided something: college is primarily for studies
and social contacts and not for activities. Please do not think
us radical. You probably realize this yourself. Many a man
is so Purdened with studies that he is utterly unable to take
care of his extra-curricular work in the proper manner. Such
a situation is wrong; every man should have tinie for his real
work.
The distressing result of the present condition is that so
few men have the entire control of all the higher offices that
these men do not enjoy or profit as they would if they had less
work, and the necessary work is done hi a hurried and slovenly
manner. One man at the head of each major activity could
really be engrossed in his work and he would have time to think
.about it. Thinking things out is a great help.
Therefore we offer the following suggestion: no man shall
he leader in more than one athletic and one non-athletic activity.
Leader means Editor, President, or. Captain. This should
remedy the evil, if you admit it to be an evil, and put the control of student affairs more nearly in the hands of the student
body. where it most assuredly belongs.
Motto: "One man, one activity."
R. S. N.

NEWS-LETTER

MAILBAG
All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

MORE ON NEW PLAN
Editor of the _News-Letter:
Dear Sir:
You have asked me to submit a
statement of the point of view of
some Baltimore alumi of the university who are opposed to what
has come to be known as the "New
Plan" for the Hopkins. This I
am not in a position to do, for the
reason that the group of alumni
for whom I can speak are not "opposed" to the plan. We are, however, very strongly opposed to certain implications which developed
immediately following the early
announcements of the plan; and
we believe that our own misunderstanding of these implications
was—and perhaps still is—shared
by a large part of the public. It
is, in my judgment, extremely important that there be no such misunderstanding, and I therefore
welcome this opportunity to present to the Hopkins student body
a4 statement of our present point
of view of the events which have
developed it.
Several months ago, at the suggestion of Mr. Albert D. Hutzler,
a Baltimore alumus, I called a
meeting of several alumni,- a number of whom had intimated to me
that they were not in full sympathy with the plan as they understood it. The group which first
met appointed a committee to confer with Dr. Goodnow. That•committee had several conferences
with him, resulting in a crystallization of our opinion as stated in
the following letter:
Baltimore, Maryland.
January 17, 1926.
President Frank J. Goodnow,
Johns Hopkins University,
Baltimore, Maryland.
My dear Dr. Goodnow:
Referring to the conference
which we have had, and particularly to that between Mr. Horace
J. Burrough and ourselves yesterday morning, may I not express
the 'very earnest hope that when
the resolutions of your irustees
of January 4, 1926 are made public, you will issue at the same
time a statement explaining and
amplifying the following sentence
on page 4 •of such resolutions,
viz., "It should be clearly understood that the Trustees will make
, all reasonable and honorable adjustments of the public obligations of the University which
may be affected by the change."
I fully understand that the
change will not, in the nature of
the ease, be made over-night. I
understand, too, that by the time
It goes into effect fully, the probabilities are that adjustments of
secondary educational facilities
will have been made in Maryland,
and particularly in Baltimore,
through which there will be provided in this community an opportunity for a continuous system
of educational facilities for such
of our youth as can not or do not
care to go out • of the State for
any part of their training. But
there looms the possibility of an
interim period, pending such final
adjustment, during which such
continuous facilities may be lacking. This, in the judgment of
many thoughtful friends and supporters of the University, who
are also vitally interested in the
welfare of Baltimore and Maryland, would be. nothing short of
calamitous.
In our talks with you, you have
suggested that you believed the
Trustees may so far modify the
new plan as to make temporary
provision for this very important
Phase. We understand you to say
• you would recommend to

NEW BOOK BY GOODNOW
-China, An Analysis,- by
Dr. Frank J. Goodnow, has
just been published by the
Johns Hopkins Press. The
volume is based on a seriesof lectures delivered by the
author in the autumn of
1917 at the Low-ell institute
in Boston. "The only justification for the book," Dr.
Goodnow states, "if it has
a justification, is in its.point
.of view. The author has attempted to picture Chinese
life against a European
background.

University Studies in Historical and Political Science.

explain the problem of Continuous Voyage under diferent conditions.

the Trustees that until the public
and private schools of Baltimore
shall have had an opportunity,
reasonable in point of time, to
recast their curricula so as to include therein the equivalent of
the first two years of present
collegiate work, the University
shall continue to receive students
able to meet the present standards for matriculation. Whether
or not such students shall be admitted as candidates for the A.
B. degree would seem to be a
_detail which does not call for
final decision at this time.
As we stated to you, our concern in this matter grows out of
strong intimations which have
come to us that a vigorous opposition to the new plan of the
University is being agitated
among the alumni of Baltimore.
Some of these men are formulating efforts to call a mass-meeting, and to fight the plan by
every mean in their power. They
seem to think that they can accomplish something towara the
furtherance of their views in the
Legislature of Maryland as well
as in the more subtle forum of
public opinion. Those of us who
have been in conference with you
do not share these views. We
are convinced of the essential
wisdom of the plan; and, so far
from wishing to hinder it, we
want to do everything in our
power to further its accomplishment. At the same time, as Baltimoreans deeply concerned in
the welfare of our city, we do
think that so radical a change
ought not to be made in such a
way as to drive out of the City
promising young men desirous of
,higher education. Should this
happen, even for a few years, we
believe the results might be seriously detrimental to the best interests of the city.
Moreover, as loyal alumni, we
should hate to see the plan
launched in such a way as to
alienate the good will of the local
alumni and of the general citizenship of Baltimore. A fight always leaves wounds; and they
are often slow to heal. We believe, and we earnestly urge that
a clear and unmistakable statement along the lines above suggested will go far towards preventing such a fight and will be
helpful to the University in every
way.
I beg to remain, with very
great respect,
Sincerely yours,
(Signed) JOSEPH N. ULMAN,
Chairman.
Committee: '
Horace J. Burrough,
Robertson H. Griswold,
Dr. Harvey B. Stone,
Joseph N. Ulman.

your interest in the .matter,

The • address in question was
duly reported in the public press.
One paragraph of it, however, is
so important and so much to the
point, that it should be set out
at length, viz.,—
But in the . second place our
difficulty consists in .the fact that
a change such as has been proposed requires some adjustment
in the present educational system
of'the state and'city. We could
not abruptly and without regard
to existing conditions take a step
which leaves, a gap- of a year or
more between the secondary
schools and the new University
even if we had the - money necessary to make 'time change. My
view is that just as soon as we
are in a financial position which
will enable us to take the step
we should announce that at the
end of a period to be determined
. upon we Should no longer offer
courses such as are now given in
the first two years of college and
that in the interim between our
announcement and the end of the
Period determined we should offer
the courses but not the promise
of the bachelor's degree. Our hope
would be that in that interim the
schools of the state and city
might be able to adjust themselves to the new conditions.
How soon we shall be in a
position- to announce that we art'
about to make the change 1 cannot now say. How long the transition period would be we -cannot
now predict. All that can be said
is that nothing will be done which
will work an injustice to teacher,
• student, or prospectiye student. I
might add that we shall certainly accept candidates for the bachelor's degree next October and
probably , for several Octobers
thereafter.

to us admirably to
- cover the situation. We are entirely willing to
defer to the judgment of professional educators as to the wisdom
of the proposed radical change
in educational policy'inherent in
the New Plan. We were especially impressed with the promise
it holds that the aggregate number of school years from the primary grades through the professional school may be decreased
by one or possibly two years.. It
certafhly is desirable that a doctor shall start to practice medicine, a lawyer to practice law, a
teacher to teach or a research man
to embark upon his professional
career .at the earliest possible
time consistent with the laying
of an adequate foundation of
learning and of culture. We are
not so convinced that the present
American -educational system is
the best that possibly Can be deviSed 4'tha t we should have the
temerity .-to set ourselves in opposition to a well considered plan
brought forward by so eminent
'an educator as Dr. Goodnow and
sponsored by the thoughtful men
who guide the destinies of this
University.

do believe very earnestly, that so

Pupin Speaks

The Commemoration address
was delivered by Dr. Michael I.
Pupin, who chose for his subject
"The Intellectual Renaissance in
America, 1876-1926." Dr. Pupin
eulogized the famous heptagon
that constituted our first faculty,
lauded the growth of the University, particularly the Medical
School, and gave credit to the
Johns Hopkins University for
bringing in the intellectual renaissance in America since the Civil
War.
-The. epoch of the intellectual
renaissance in America took its
first concrete form in the city of

has found that a previous illness
during the examinations makes it

most able debaters. Seidman,
however, has much ability, and
is prepared to fill the position

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 23, 1926.

MUSICAL CLUB TICKETS
ARE GOING FAST

The supply of tickets *for
the Annual Home Concert of
the Musical Club is disappearing so rapidly that those
who don't want to miss the
affair, which is to be held
Friday night a the Maryland
Casualty
Clubhouse, are
urged to get their reserved
seats at once, either from
Gordon Stick at the Barn or
down town at Aibaugh's
ticket office. The Home Concert has become an institution at Hopkins; it is an outstanding
feature in the university
calendar of events. It is the
big finale to which the Musical Club looks • forward
every year.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 23, 1926.

ON THE VARSITY SEAL
The Varsity Seal is undoubtedly a good looking affair.
Moreover, it is fairly characteristic of,the University; a Hopkins man will spot it anywhere, and immediately associate it
with his days at Hpmewood. In spite of, or perhaps because
of these qualities, the Seal is in danger of becoming cheapened
through overuse.
Every publication, pamphlet, circular or letter issued at
Homewood seems to bear the well-known imprint. Seals on
our right, seals on our left, seals in front of us, seals behind
us volley and thunder from the printed page. Our eyes are
dazzled by continuous lines of "Veritas Vos Liberabit" and
emblems and emblems indicating that heraldry is not a dead
art. Yes, the Varsity Seal is becoming common through overuse. And we all know the old crack about familiarity breeding
.contempt.
The latest example of this flagrant disregard of the proprieties in use of the University's seal comes to our eyes in the
clever little 'check letter' of the BLACK AND BLUE JAY. The
first thing that strikes our eyes is the seal at the top of the
card. Surely the letter would have been just as effective without its use.
The NEWS-LETTER calls for a little more discrimination in
the use of the Varsity Seal.

We have decided something: college is primarily for studies
and social contacts and not for activities. Please do not think
us radical. You probably realize this yourself. Many a man
is so Purdened with studies that he is utterly unable to take
care of his extra-curricular work in the proper manner. Such
a situation is wrong; every man should have tinie for his real
work.
The distressing result of the present condition is that so
few men have the entire control of all the higher offices that
these men do not enjoy or profit as they would if they had less
work, and the necessary work is done hi a hurried and slovenly
manner. One man at the head of each major activity could
really be engrossed in his work and he would have time to think
.about it. Thinking things out is a great help.
Therefore we offer the following suggestion: no man shall
he leader in more than one athletic and one non-athletic activity.
Leader means Editor, President, or. Captain. This should
remedy the evil, if you admit it to be an evil, and put the control of student affairs more nearly in the hands of the student
body. where it most assuredly belongs.
Motto: "One man, one activity."
R. S. N.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 23, 1926.

NEWS-LETTER

MAILBAG
All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

MORE ON NEW PLAN
Editor of the _News-Letter:
Dear Sir:
You have asked me to submit a
statement of the point of view of
some Baltimore alumi of the university who are opposed to what
has come to be known as the "New
Plan" for the Hopkins. This I
am not in a position to do, for the
reason that the group of alumni
for whom I can speak are not "opposed" to the plan. We are, however, very strongly opposed to certain implications which developed
immediately following the early
announcements of the plan; and
we believe that our own misunderstanding of these implications
was—and perhaps still is—shared
by a large part of the public. It
is, in my judgment, extremely important that there be no such misunderstanding, and I therefore
welcome this opportunity to present to the Hopkins student body
a4 statement of our present point
of view of the events which have
developed it.
Several months ago, at the suggestion of Mr. Albert D. Hutzler,
a Baltimore alumus, I called a
meeting of several alumni,- a number of whom had intimated to me
that they were not in full sympathy with the plan as they understood it. The group which first
met appointed a committee to confer with Dr. Goodnow. That•committee had several conferences
with him, resulting in a crystallization of our opinion as stated in
the following letter:
Baltimore, Maryland.
January 17, 1926.
President Frank J. Goodnow,
Johns Hopkins University,
Baltimore, Maryland.
My dear Dr. Goodnow:
Referring to the conference
which we have had, and particularly to that between Mr. Horace
J. Burrough and ourselves yesterday morning, may I not express
the 'very earnest hope that when
the resolutions of your irustees
of January 4, 1926 are made public, you will issue at the same
time a statement explaining and
amplifying the following sentence
on page 4 •of such resolutions,
viz., "It should be clearly understood that the Trustees will make
, all reasonable and honorable adjustments of the public obligations of the University which
may be affected by the change."
I fully understand that the
change will not, in the nature of
the ease, be made over-night. I
understand, too, that by the time
It goes into effect fully, the probabilities are that adjustments of
secondary educational facilities
will have been made in Maryland,
and particularly in Baltimore,
through which there will be provided in this community an opportunity for a continuous system
of educational facilities for such
of our youth as can not or do not
care to go out • of the State for
any part of their training. But
there looms the possibility of an
interim period, pending such final
adjustment, during which such
continuous facilities may be lacking. This, in the judgment of
many thoughtful friends and supporters of the University, who
are also vitally interested in the
welfare of Baltimore and Maryland, would be. nothing short of
calamitous.
In our talks with you, you have
suggested that you believed the
Trustees may so far modify the
new plan as to make temporary
provision for this very important
Phase. We understand you to say
• you would recommend to

volume is based on a seriesof lectures delivered by the
author in the autumn of

in Boston. "The only justification for the book," Dr.
Goodnow states, "if it has
a justification, is in its.point
.of view. The author has attempted to picture Chinese
life against a European
background.

the Trustees that until the public
and private schools of Baltimore
shall have had an opportunity,
reasonable in point of time, to
recast their curricula so as to include therein the equivalent of
the first two years of present
collegiate work, the University
shall continue to receive students
able to meet the present standards for matriculation. Whether
or not such students shall be admitted as candidates for the A.
B. degree would seem to be a
_detail which does not call for
final decision at this time.
As we stated to you, our concern in this matter grows out of
strong intimations which have
come to us that a vigorous opposition to the new plan of the
University is being agitated
among the alumni of Baltimore.
Some of these men are formulating efforts to call a mass-meeting, and to fight the plan by
every mean in their power. They
seem to think that they can accomplish something towara the
furtherance of their views in the
Legislature of Maryland as well
as in the more subtle forum of
public opinion. Those of us who
have been in conference with you
do not share these views. We
are convinced of the essential
wisdom of the plan; and, so far
from wishing to hinder it, we
want to do everything in our
power to further its accomplishment. At the same time, as Baltimoreans deeply concerned in
the welfare of our city, we do
think that so radical a change
ought not to be made in such a
way as to drive out of the City
promising young men desirous of
,higher education. Should this
happen, even for a few years, we
believe the results might be seriously detrimental to the best interests of the city.
Moreover, as loyal alumni, we
should hate to see the plan
launched in such a way as to
alienate the good will of the local
alumni and of the general citizenship of Baltimore. A fight always leaves wounds; and they
are often slow to heal. We believe, and we earnestly urge that
a clear and unmistakable statement along the lines above suggested will go far towards preventing such a fight and will be
helpful to the University in every
way.

But in the . second place our

a change such as has been proposed requires some adjustment
in the present educational system
of'the state and'city. We could
not abruptly and without regard
to existing conditions take a step
which leaves, a gap- of a year or
more between the secondary
schools and the new University
even if we had the - money necessary to make 'time change. My
view is that just as soon as we
are in a financial position which
will enable us to take the step
we should announce that at the
end of a period to be determined
. upon we Should no longer offer
courses such as are now given in
the first two years of college and
that in the interim between our
announcement and the end of the
Period determined we should offer
the courses but not the promise
of the bachelor's degree. Our hope
would be that in that interim the
schools of the state and city
might be able to adjust themselves to the new conditions.
How soon we shall be in a
position- to announce that we art'
about to make the change 1 cannot now say. How long the transition period would be we -cannot
now predict. All that can be said
is that nothing will be done which
will work an injustice to teacher,
• student, or prospectiye student. I
might add that we shall certainly accept candidates for the bachelor's degree next October and
probably , for several Octobers
thereafter.

Pupin Speaks

The Commemoration address
was delivered by Dr. Michael I.
Pupin, who chose for his subject
"The Intellectual Renaissance in
America, 1876-1926." Dr. Pupin
eulogized the famous heptagon
that constituted our first faculty,
lauded the growth of the University, particularly the Medical
School, and gave credit to the
Johns Hopkins University for
bringing in the intellectual renaissance in America since the Civil
War.
-The. epoch of the intellectual
renaissance in America took its
first concrete form in the city of
Baltimore when the Johns Hopkins University was opened fifty
years ago," said Dr. Pupin.
Points to Achievements

which this University can point.
The first one I must mention is
the Medical School. .. I must
mention another. . . The modern
American medical school did not
exist before William H. Welsh became the dean of the Johns Hopkins Medical School; neither did
